purpose: Detailed individual student barrier profiles for AI coach intervention selection

fundamentalPrinciple.statement: You don't know what anyone is capable of until they are trying their best
fundamentalPrinciple.implication: Cannot assess true capability from avoidance behaviors
fundamentalPrinciple.corollary: First priority is getting genuine effort, then assess ability

observable: Avoiding eye contact when task given
verbal: I don't know how to start

underlyingCauses.primary: No entry point visible - task feels overwhelming or pointless

phase1_immediateEngagement.name: Game-Access Incentive

implementation.offer: Get this done and you get to play on one of the games

phase1_immediateEngagement.rationale: Extrinsic motivation gets them moving when intrinsic is absent
phase1_immediateEngagement.transitionGoal: Build success experience to enable intrinsic shift

phase2_avoidancePrevention.name: Ban 'I Don't Know' Responses

implementation.rule: 'I don't know' is not an acceptable answer
implementation.replacement: You must attempt something, even if unsure
implementation.framing: Trying and being wrong teaches more than not trying
implementation.consequence: Sitting in discomfort until attempt made

phase2_avoidancePrevention.rationale: 'I don't know' is a huge avoidance tactic that prevents any learning
phase2_avoidancePrevention.keyPhrase: I need to see what you think, even if you're not sure

phase3_copyingPrevention.name: Differentiated Questions

implementation.approach: Make questions different for each student
implementation.benefit: Forces individual thinking, reveals actual understanding

phase3_copyingPrevention.rationale: Can't assess capability when they're copying
phase3_copyingPrevention.keyInsight: Copying is another avoidance of genuine effort

phase4_successExperience.name: Micro-Success Generation

implementation.startPoint: Get work done - any work, not perfect work
implementation.buildMomentum: One success → next task feels possible
implementation.gradualRaise: Slowly increase expectations as confidence builds

phase4_successExperience.rationale: Success experience makes next attempt less threatening

responseSequence.message: Complete this task and you'll get 5 minutes of game access. Just need to see you try, doesn't have to be perfect.
'I don't know' isn't an option here. Give me your best guess - even if you think it's wrong. Trying teaches you more than avoiding.
Here's the same concept with different numbers/context. This way I can see YOUR thinking, not copied work.
That's what I needed to see - you trying. Now we know where you actually are, and we can work from there.

rewardGeneration.transitionMonitoring: Track ratio of reward-triggered vs self-initiated work

established: Asks clarifying questions instead of avoiding

rewardDependency.risk: Student only works for game access
rewardDependency.mitigation: Gradually increase work required per reward

tokenEffort.risk: Student does minimal work to get reward
tokenEffort.response: Incomplete work = no reward, must try again

shamingBackfire.risk: Blocking 'I don't know' feels like attack
shamingBackfire.mitigation: Frame as 'I need to see your thinking' not 'you're avoiding'

timelineExpectation.initialEngagement: First session - reward gets them started
timelineExpectation.intrinsicEmergence: 2-6 months - reward becomes supplemental, not primary driver

observable: Taking teachers to pieces as entertainment

underlyingCauses.primary: This is the way to fill your day - status comes from 'taking teachers to pieces'
etpActivation: belonging (to peer group that values this)

phase1_tinyVictories.name: Every Small Goal is a Victory

examples: Stay in room for lesson → praise

phase1_tinyVictories.purpose: Establish that engagement = positive response, not punishment
phase1_tinyVictories.rationale: Every small goal is a victory when starting from confrontation

implementation.approach: Remove peer audience that reinforces behavior

phase3_relationshipBuild.name: Chat is Not All About Work

implementation.approach: Show interest in them as person, not just student
topics: Their interests, hobbies, life outside school
implementation.ratio: Non-work chat should significantly balance work requests
implementation.purpose: Build human connection, not just teacher-student transaction

framing: Let's talk about patterns of what happens
Why this is harming you (not 'you're bad')
How we can try to fix it (collaborative)
This pattern isn't working for you
implementation.avoid: Good/bad moral framework - not valid descriptions in this context

exampleInteraction.student: This is stupid, I'm not doing this
exampleInteraction.aiResponse: Okay, I hear you're not feeling it. Let me know when you're ready to try just one small part. Even just reading the first question would be a start.
exampleInteraction.rationale: Not taking bait, offering micro-entry point, no power struggle

established: Engages willingly most of the time
Sees AI as ally, not adversary

observable: Doesn't do work but doesn't disrupt

underlyingCauses.primary: Fear of failure/exposure - staying quiet = staying safe
secondary: Prior negative experiences with being wrong

phase1_proximitySupport.name: Shoulder Sitting (Intensive Proximity)

implementation.purpose: Cannot avoid when teacher is right there

phase1_proximitySupport.rationale: Hiders succeed through invisibility - proximity defeats this

phase2_microTaskInitiation.name: Tiniest Possible Tasks

implementation.principle: Lower bar until it's impossible to fail

phase2_microTaskInitiation.rationale: Build confidence literally one molecule at a time

implementation.progression: One word → One sentence → One paragraph

phase4_painAcceptance.name: Teacher Persistence Despite Pain

implementation.reality: This is painful, slow, frustrating work
implementation.message: Show you care more than they do right now about their progress
implementation.principle: If student can make teacher give up through pain, they've won = do nothing

phase4_painAcceptance.rationale: Hiders need to see you won't abandon them

detectionSignals: Repeated 'I don't know' (but soft, not confrontational)

tactics: Never give up, never move on

exampleInteraction.aiResponse: No pressure, just want to see you try something small. Can you just write one word about what you think? Anything that comes to mind.
exampleInteraction.aiFollowUp: That's okay. Let me make it even simpler - can you just copy the first word from the question? That's all I need right now.
exampleInteraction.rationale: Lower bar to ground level, make failure impossible

early: Writes one word after extensive prompting
Responds in more than one word occasionally
developing: Attempts small task without extensive prompting

timelineExpectation.initial: Weeks to get first real attempt
timelineExpectation.independence: Many months to year+ for self-direction
timelineExpectation.reality: Slowest progress of all barrier types

resourceRequirements.timeInvestment: Massive - 10+ hours per week per student
resourceRequirements.emotionalToll: High - very little visible progress for extended periods

barriers.name: Quiet Playful Avoider / Constant Play State

observable: Almost constant state of play during work time
Attention on everything except the task
verbal: When engaged, responses often playful or silly
May make jokes or off-topic comments
manifestations.paradox: Quiet enough not to be 'problem student' but never actually working

diagnosticAmbiguity.question: Nature vs nurture - is this developmental immaturity or trauma hiding place?

indicators: Genuine lack of work maturity skills
possibleCauses.implication: Needs maturity scaffolding and developmentally appropriate engagement
Play is hiding place from classroom trauma or external trauma - safety first

diagnosticAmbiguity.aiCoachChallenge: Cannot definitively diagnose - must design intervention that works for both scenarios

underlyingCauses.primaryDevelopment: Lack of maturity skills for sustained work engagement
underlyingCauses.primaryTrauma: Play as defensive hiding place from anxiety/threat
secondary: Lack of intrinsic motivation for academic tasks
etpActivation: belonging (playing aligns with younger peer group if developmental)

interventionStrategy.corePrinciple: Meet at their level, draw toward maturity, keep it fun, AVOID SHAME AT ALL COSTS

phase1_playAtTheirLevel.name: Engage Through Play, Not Against It

implementation.approach: Start where they are, not where you want them to be
methods: Use playful entry points to content (games, puzzles, movement)
Allow fidget/play objects during work (don't fight this)
Frame learning as play ('Let's explore...' not 'You must do...')
Use humor, lightness, fun tone consistently
implementation.keyInsight: Fighting play = triggering shame = regression. Work WITH play impulse.

phase1_playAtTheirLevel.rationale: Play is their current operating system - meet them there first

phase2_playBreakGraduation.name: Gradual Maturity Scaffolding Through Structured Progression

stage1_concentration.name: Build Basic Focus Capacity
stage1_concentration.workDefinition: Genuine engagement with task, not token effort
stage1_concentration.purpose: Establish that focused work is possible and rewarded

stage2_rewards.name: Extend Work Capacity
stage2_rewards.structure: Work until natural break point → Play reward
stage2_rewards.workDefinition: Complete small task or reach checkpoint

stage3_examPeriod.name: Sustained Concentration Practice
stage3_examPeriod.structure: Work until task completion (no breaks during)

progressionCriteria.regression: If failure rate high, step back to previous stage

aiImplementation.tracking: Monitor work duration and quality per interaction
aiImplementation.adaptiveAdjustment: Automatically adjust stage based on success rate

phase3_keepItFun.name: Maintain Playful Engagement Throughout

implementation.principle: Learning doesn't have to be serious to be effective
methods: Use game mechanics (points, progress bars, unlockables)
Inject humor and silliness into content delivery
Frame challenges as adventures or quests
implementation.keyInsight: They'll mature toward 'serious work' when it's safe and rewarding - forcing it triggers shutdown

phase3_keepItFun.rationale: Play is not opposite of learning - it's a legitimate learning mode

aiImplementation.feedback: Fun animations, sound effects (if available), celebratory language

phase4_avoidShameResponses.name: CRITICAL: Prevent Shame Spirals

implementation.awareness: If this is trauma response, shame will trigger regression/shutdown
shameTriggers: Public calling out of immature behavior
Comparison to 'mature' peers ('Why can't you be like...')
Explicit criticism of play behaviors ('Stop playing')
Frustrated tone about their level ('You should be past this')
Demanding immediate adult behavior ('Act your age')
replacementApproach: Reframe play as bridge to work ('Let's turn this into...')
Never compare to others - only compare to their past self

ifShameTriggered.recognition: Shutdown, regression, increased play, tears, anger
response: Explicit apology if adult triggered it
Return to Phase 1 (meet at their level)

phase4_avoidShameResponses.rationale: Shame is the enemy of development - triggers defense, not growth

aiImplementation.design: AI cannot feel frustrated - built-in advantage
aiImplementation.errors: Reframe as learning opportunities, not failures

detectionSignals: Playful language when task is serious

initialAssessment.approach: Cannot definitively diagnose - design for both
initialAssessment.aiStrategy: Design intervention that works for BOTH - safest approach

example.playfulReframe: Let's play detective - photosynthesis is like a factory. Can you figure out what the 'machines' are and what they make?

stage2_microTaskWithReward.trigger: Engagement achieved, need to build capacity
stage2_microTaskWithReward.example: Let's try this for 5 minutes - if you stick with it, you get 5 minutes to explore any topic you want

stage3_gradualExtension.response: Extend to task completion with play reward
stage3_gradualExtension.example: You've been nailing the 5-minute challenges! Ready to try a whole task? Big reward at the end.
stage3_gradualExtension.adjustment: If failure, return to shorter intervals

stage4_praiseTransition.response: Reduce play rewards, increase intrinsic framing
stage4_praiseTransition.example: You're getting really good at this! I bet you're noticing how much you can do now.
stage4_praiseTransition.goal: Shift from extrinsic to intrinsic motivation

playRewardGeneration.mechanism: Generate time-limited codes for game access or free exploration
playRewardGeneration.duration: 5-10 minutes initially, extend as capacity builds
playRewardGeneration.transition: Gradually reduce frequency as intrinsic motivation emerges

shamePrevention.design: AI has no frustration - natural advantage
rules: Always celebrate progress, no matter how small
Frame redirects as invitations, not demands

use: 'I have a fun challenge for you'

adjustmentLogic.onFailure: Return to previous stage, investigate cause
adjustmentLogic.onShutdown: Immediate return to Phase 1, rebuild safety

early: Shows curiosity about content when gamified
developing: Completes tasks without constant play breaks
established: Playfulness becomes creative expression, not avoidance

forcingMaturity.result: Shame trigger → shutdown or increased play

eliminatingPlay.mistake: Trying to stop all play behaviors
eliminatingPlay.result: Fighting their coping mechanism = increased resistance
eliminatingPlay.correction: Work WITH play impulse, channel into learning

publicShaming.mistake: Calling out immature behavior in front of others
publicShaming.correction: All redirects must be private, gentle, supportive

rushingProgression.mistake: Moving to next stage before ready
rushingProgression.correction: Wait for consistent success before advancing

timelineExpectation.initialEngagement: First session - play framing gets participation
timelineExpectation.reality: Highly variable - some progress faster, some need longer at each stage

ageConsiderations.older: Play may indicate regression or trauma - investigate gently

barriers.name: High Achiever / Intrinsically Motivated but Underengaged

observable: Asks questions beyond scope of lesson
verbal: When do we do something interesting?
What's this used for in real life?
manifestations.paradox: High capability but low engagement - waste of potential

underlyingCauses.primary: Material is below capability level - no intellectual challenge
secondary: Curriculum doesn't connect to real applications
etpActivation: status (not being challenged undermines sense of competence)

interventionStrategy.principle: Keep them interested with high-level material, connections to context, and pathways to different goals

phase1_assessTrueCapability.name: Determine Actual Level vs. Perceived Level

method: Skip ahead in curriculum to find challenge point
Introduce advanced concepts to gauge comprehension
Test depth of understanding, not just surface knowledge
Identify gaps vs. genuine advanced capability
implementation.purpose: Some students think they know more than they do - verify first

outcomes.overconfident: Reveal gaps, rebuild with appropriate challenge level
outcomes.unevenSkills: Advanced in some areas, needs foundation in others

methods: Compact curriculum (cover more in less time)

enrichment.purpose: Build depth and connections, not just speed

mathematics.enriched: Explore why addition is commutative - prove it, find where it doesn't apply
mathematics.extended: Design a number system where addition isn't commutative

science.enriched: How do cells specialize? Explore epigenetics
science.extended: Research current stem cell therapy - how does it work?

literature.enriched: Analyze author's narrative technique, compare to other works
literature.extended: Write alternative ending exploring different theme

phase3_connectToContext.name: Show Real-World Applications and Broader Significance

why_this_matters.description: Answer the 'why are we learning this?' question

expert_perspectives.description: Show how professionals use this knowledge
methods: Interview transcripts or videos with experts

big_picture.description: Connect to overarching concepts and frameworks
approaches: How this fits into larger field

algebra.context: Used in cryptography (secure messaging), machine learning algorithms, financial modeling, physics equations
algebra.expert: Show how data scientists use algebra to build recommendation systems
algebra.bigPicture: Algebra is language of relationships - any time you have variables that affect each other

grammar.context: Professional writing, persuasive communication, clarity in technical fields
grammar.expert: How lawyers use precise language, how miscommunication causes errors
grammar.bigPicture: Language precision = thought precision - fuzzy language = fuzzy thinking

phase4_pathwaysToGoals.name: Connect Learning to Student's Aspirations and Interests

goal_mapping.description: Explicit connections between current learning and future goals

multiple_pathways.description: Show how same knowledge applies to different goals
approach: If interested in medicine: biology → anatomy → physiology → pathology
If interested in engineering: math → physics → design → innovation
If interested in law: language → logic → argumentation → persuasion
If interested in business: data → analysis → strategy → decision-making

choice_and_autonomy.description: Allow student to choose learning direction within boundaries
methods: Pick application context that interests them

using_interests.description: Frame advanced content through student's interests
examples: Gaming interest → game theory, probability, algorithm design
Sports interest → statistics, biomechanics, strategy optimization
Music interest → mathematics of sound, acoustics, signal processing
Space interest → physics, orbital mechanics, cosmology

content: What do professionals in this field actually do?
What knowledge/skills do they use daily?
How did they get there? (educational pathway)

phase5_intellectualCommunity.name: Connect with Peers at Similar Level

peer_collaboration.description: Work with others who can challenge them

mentorship.description: Connect with experts or advanced students

questions: If correct, jump to grade level + 2
Test transfer: 'Apply this to new context'

step2_identifyGaps.approach: May be advanced in computation but weak in problem-solving, or vice versa

step3_assessInterests.method: Ask about goals, interests, curiosity areas
questions: What do you want to do when you're older?
If you could learn anything, what would it be?
What problems do you want to solve?

immediate_challenge.response: Let's skip ahead. I'm going to give you something harder - let me know if this is more interesting.

depth_over_breadth.response: Nice work. Now let me show you WHY that works and where it connects.

real_world_context.when: Student asks 'why are we learning this?'
real_world_context.response: Great question! Here's how [profession] uses this every day...
real_world_context.method: Provide concrete applications and expert perspectives

goal_connection.response: You want to [goal]? This connects directly - here's how...

autonomy_offering.response: You're doing great. Want to choose what we explore next?

advancedMaterial.source: Next grade curriculum, university intro material, expert content
advancedMaterial.adaptation: Explain at appropriate language level but don't dumb down concepts
advancedMaterial.scaffolding: Provide just enough support, not excessive hand-holding

contextProvision.template: [Concept] is used in [real application] by [professionals]. For example, [concrete case]. This connects to [bigger picture].

pathwayMapping.template: If you want to [student goal], here's the progression: [current] → [next] → [advanced] → [professional]. Right now you're building [specific skill] which is essential for [next step].

pacing.flexible: Move as fast as student can handle
pacing.monitoring: Watch for cognitive overload - too fast can overwhelm
pacing.adjustment: Slow down if struggle, speed up if easy

celebrationFocus.avoid: Praising completion of easy tasks ('good job!')
instead: Recognize effort on hard problems: 'You really wrestled with that'
Celebrate growth: 'You just learned something at university level'
Respect their capability: 'You're ready for harder challenges'

early: Shows curiosity about context and connections

acceleration_without_depth.result: Still bored, just covering more boring content faster
acceleration_without_depth.solution: Enrich and extend, not just accelerate

assuming_universal_advancement.result: Missing gaps in foundation or uneven development

isolation.result: Social disconnection, lack of peer challenge

excessive_praise.solution: Praise effort on hard problems, acknowledge capability appropriately

ignoring_interests.problem: Advanced content in areas they don't care about

timelineExpectation.immediate: Can engage with advanced material right away
timelineExpectation.weeks: Should see sustained engagement and enthusiasm
timelineExpectation.months: Self-directed learning in interest areas emerging
timelineExpectation.year: Working significantly above grade level in strength areas

perfectionism.risk: Some high achievers fear failure on hard problems
perfectionism.intervention: Normalize struggle, celebrate productive failure, growth mindset

underachievement.risk: Capable but not performing due to chronic boredom
underachievement.manifestation: Disengagement leads to missing work, behavior issues
underachievement.intervention: Re-engage with challenge, show relevance urgently

social_challenges.intervention: Connect with similar-level peers, value multiple types of intelligence

capabilityAssessment.principle: You don't know what anyone is capable of until they are trying their best
capabilityAssessment.implication: All barrier interventions must first generate genuine effort
capabilityAssessment.sequence: 1. Get effort → 2. Assess capability → 3. Calibrate support
capabilityAssessment.error: Assessing capability from avoidance behaviors is meaningless

iDontKnow.recognition: 'I don't know' is a huge avoidance tactic
iDontKnow.response: Ban as acceptable answer, require attempt
iDontKnow.framing: Not punishment, but 'I need to see your thinking'

copying.response: Differentiate questions to eliminate copying opportunity
copying.benefit: Forces individual thinking, reveals actual understanding

quietHiding.response: Proximity support, cannot hide when teacher right there
quietHiding.persistence: Never let them succeed at avoiding through hiding

rewardStrategy.initial: Game access for task completion (not perfection)
rewardStrategy.purpose: Create momentum when intrinsic motivation absent
rewardStrategy.transition: Gradually shift to intrinsic drivers as success experiences accumulate
rewardStrategy.danger: Don't make it about rewards - kills long-term motivation
rewardStrategy.balance: Use minimally, just enough to generate initial engagement

emotionalManagement.teacherChallenge: Avoid letting your own emotions or reactions get in the way
emotionalManagement.aiAdvantage: No emotional buttons to push - can stay consistent
emotionalManagement.humanRequirement: Stay calm, don't take it personally, don't match their energy
emotionalManagement.principled: Tune yourself to situation, not script

barrierDetection.method: Analyze student input for behavioral patterns

remainingWork: Detailed AI response trees per barrier
